pullRequest.body:
If `A` is an `R`-algebra and `d : A → M` is a derivation, then for any polynomial `f : R[X]` and any `a : A`,
`d(f(a)) = f'(a) d a`.

---

There are shorter proofs of this result, but in my view the most sensible proof is to interpret both sides of
the equation as derivations R[X] \to M, and then to check that they agree in the case f = X.

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body: Can you split the PR in two, opening another one with only the `R[X]`-module structure? It is an important construction (thanks for adding it!) and it deserves its own discussion. Feel free to ask my review.
bors d+

Thanks :tada:

If I change the name from `toFun` to `apply` on line 150, then I assume this will be ok, except that the code will not work until #8151 is merged. How should I proceed?
Yes, if you make that change I'm happy for you to put this on the queue even though CI will fail; as you say, it will succeed when it lands.
Alternatively, if you wait 5 minutes you can just merge master :)

In general, I'm a bit hesitant about the name `comp_aeval`. Because the expressions are not literally compositions. What do you think of `evalAEval`?

This is a type, so
```suggestion
@[nolint unusedArguments] def CompAEval (R M : Type*) {A : Type*} [CommSemiring R] [Semiring A]
```
throughout
Thanks very much for pointing this out.

Instead of using a type synonym, I think a one-field structure might be clearer here:
```lean
import Mathlib.Logic.Equiv.TransferInstance
```
```lean
structure CompAEval (R M: Type*) {A : Type*} [CommSemiring R] [Semiring A]
    [Algebra R A][AddCommMonoid M] [Module A M] [Module R M] [IsScalarTower R A M] (_ : A) where
  val : M

variable {R A M} [CommSemiring R] [Semiring A] (a : A) [Algebra R A] [AddCommMonoid M] [Module A M]
  [Module R M] [IsScalarTower R A M]
def CompAEval.equiv : CompAEval R M a ≃ M where
  toFun := CompAEval.val
  invFun := CompAEval.mk
  left_inv := sorry
  right_inv := sorry

instance : AddCommMonoid <| CompAEval R M a     := (CompAEval.equiv a).addCommMonoid
instance : Module R <| CompAEval R M a          := (CompAEval.equiv a).module R
instance : Module A <| CompAEval R M a          := (CompAEval.equiv a).module A
```
Thanks, this is a much better idea!
Actually, having made the change, I'm not sure it's better. What do you think?
I'm happy with the change now.

With my suggestion above, this becomes
```suggestion
  toFun f := ⟨d (aeval a f)⟩
```
Thank you.

This is an important construction that should belong to a more basic file. Moreover, are you sure this isn't already in mathlib in some form? I am not sure, but we should have something like the `R[X]`-module structure given by an endomorphism of `M` (or at least there has been a discussion about it).

Ah, I just found [this](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib/pull/14666) mathlib3 PR that for some reason never got merged. It's probably worth to try to do everything in the right generality.

Thank you very much for your comments; it's taken me a long time to think them through. I have moved the module construction to Data.Polynomial.Module

As you say, my construction of an `R[X]`-module structure could be regarded as a special case of
a more general construction, starting from a linear map (as in the PR that you found for me).

Alternatively, one could view it the other way around: if one begins with a linear map φ,
then one could construct the corresponding `R[X]`-module as `CompAEval R M φ`. In fact, when I looked at the mathlib3 PR which you found for me (and many thanks for that!), I can see on line 60 that the `R[X]`-module structure is defined by composing with aeval in the case that the `R`-algebra is `M →ₗ[R] M`.

So each construction could be regarded as a generalization of the other. If you add the following line following line to the end of the file, then this will be clear:

`example (φ : M →ₗ[R] M) (m : CompAEval R M φ) : (X : R[X]) • m = φ • m := by simp`

On line 409 of Data.Polynomial.Module I have now added a definition of the `R[X]`-module corresponding to a linear map `φ : M →ₗ[R] M`.

```suggestion
@[simps]
def comp_aeval : Derivation R R[X] <| AEval R M a where
```
This should generate the `comp_aeval_def` lemma for you, although it might be called `comp_aeval_apply` (which is the mathlib convention for the name of such a lemma.
Thank you for your comments. Is it clear that this should be a simp lemma? (see line 150, where I need to prevent its use).

I cannot make any guarantees, of course. But my gut feeling says that 95% this will be a useful simp-lemma. Your example in line 150 is one of those edge cases where you apply the (very valid!) proof technique of bundling everything up to exploit a strong ext-lemma. But this runs against the flow of the default simp-set.

I would argue that this lemma is most likely only going to be used once.
In all other cases, it will probably be used in the reverse direction, and `simp` will take care of that.
So I think you can just inline this into the proof of `comp_aeval_eq`, possibly using a `calc`-block.
Thanks you for the suggestion.

Thank you very much for pointing this out; I've updated my comment.
Can I check whether you agree with the comment now, or should the definition be changed?
Updating the comment is enough, thanks!
